description.narrative: The proposed IFC financing would help: - increase capacity and reduce the cost of transportation on the River System benefiting multiple commodity producers, shippers and consumers; - support the agricultural development in inland Paraguay, Bolivia, Brazil and Argentina by connecting farmers to global transportation links and helping to expand feasible production areas; - support the development of iron ore and steel industries in Brazil and Argentina, respectively; - reduce harmful effects on the climate by decreasing UABL''s fuel consumption per unit transported and avoiding the use of trucks; and - encourage competing barge operators to increase their efficiency and, therefore, serve as a catalyst for increased trading activity in the region.

UABL Limited (the Company), an existing IFC client, is the largest barge operator on the Paraná-Paraguay river system in South America. The company primarily transports: - soy products and iron ore from Paraguay, Bolivia and Western Brazil for final export markets in Europe and Asia; and - petroleum products into Paraguay for domestic consumption. UABL is expanding its 2011-2013 investment program to (i) accelerate the acquisition of dry bulk barges; (ii) modify and refurbish part of its existing barge fleet; and (iii) repower existing pushboats and acquire new pushboats, tugboats and ancillary equipment to grow its river transport operations and to satisfy growing demand. The proposed project will allow UABL to further optimize its operations, increase fuel efficiency and expand the transport capacity in the River System (the Project or UBAL III).

name.narrative: UABL operates on the Paraná-Paraguay river system in South America, which starts in Corumba (Brazil) in the Upper Paraguay river and ends near Buenos Aires (Argentina) in the River Plate, and also includes the Upper Parana River between Tres Fronteras (Argentina Brazil Paraguay) and Confluencia (Argentina), covering over 2,200 kilometers of waterways, and connecting landlocked areas of Paraguay, Bolivia, and Western Brazil with the Atlantic Ocean through the River Plate.
